captions.text: MOSFILM

Attention, everybody! Ready for
shooting!
Silence!

Ready for take.
Start sound!
Rolling.
Camera!

Stop!
Camera is choked.
Camera down.

- Whatís wrong?
- The usual technical trouble.
Five minutes break for actors!
Come on, Vanya.
Camera ready.

- Ready.
- All set.

- Letís get going.
- All set. Ready for take.
Start sound!
Rolling!

- Camera!
- Camera rolling.
Scene one, take one.
WINTER EVENING IN GAGRY
Starring

Beglov -
Yevgeny YEVSTIGNEYEV

Young Beglov -
Arkady NASYROV

Arkady Grachyov -
Alexander PANKRATOV-CHYORNY

Melnikova -
Natalya GUNDAREVA

Choreographer ñ Sergey NIKONENKO
Administrator ñ Pyotr SHCHERBAKOV

Beglovís Daughter -
Svetlana AMANOVA, Anya IVANOVA
With

Georgy BURKOV
Alexander SHIRVINDT

Moscow Chamber Ballet,
Soloists L. SABITOVA, A. KLOKOV

Tap Dancers
Ye. ZERNOV, V. KIRSANOV

I. FEDOTKIN
O. FEDOTKIN, V. IVANOV
What is a variety show?

Some say
itís entertainment.

Others say that
Variety should educate.
Still others think nothing of it.

And for me, Variety
is my life.

And the last banal question:
What are your new plans?

The program
weíre working on now
is about variety shows.
About our life.

It is called ìIBMî
(Electronic Calculating Machine).

- Sorry, I donít get you.
- Thatís what I thought.

Really, what can IBM and Variety
have in common?

IBM is an image of the tendencies
we come across every day,

such as machinesÖ
programming, standardization.

So we decided to knock
IBM and Variety together

and see what
the result will be.
Good luck! Thank you.

No smoking here!
Not allowed.

- Hi, Lyosha.
- Hi.
You watched TV yesterday?
No.

The ìMan and the Lawî show was
about a director of a big store.

They nabbed him with diamonds and
gold worth a hundred thousand.

That should get him 10 years in
prison, for sure.
Or maybe even 15.

I just canít get over it.
How impudent can a fellow get?
You bet.

Kozlov, thatís no way to do
a battement!

Youíre wooden.
Itís a battement, you see?

Come on,
do a real battement.

- Hello. Have you had a class?
- Yes, sir.
Hello.
Hello.
Letís do the whole thing once again.

Repeat the first part.
Chaos and the birth of IBM.
Letís have music.
Music on!
If you need me, Iím out for a smoke.
Yes, Lyosha, only donít leave.
Wait.
I need cigarettes.

- Here.
- Thanks.

- Hi, Fyodor.
- Hi.
What drinks do you have?
Pepsi, Fanta, mineral water, beer.

Make it mineral water,
or maybe Fanta?
How old is the beer?

What difference does it make to you?
How many, one or two?
One.

- Did you watch TV last night?
- No.

You should have. It was
ìMan and the Lawî program.
About how they caught a barman.

With gold and diamonds
worth a hundred thousand rubles.
And?

What díyou mean, and? He got
20 years, with everything confiscated.
Why do you have to pester me?
Whoever told you to come here?
Why is he after me?!

I had two heart attacks! Iím forever
in the Intensive Care Unit!

I keep awake till 4 a.m., thinking
and thinking, and he works me up!
Why is he doing that?
Are you Beglov?
Yes.
Iím Arkady Grachyov.

You see, Alexei Ivanovich,
itís like this.
I made inquiries

and found out that you
were once a tap dancer.

And, except you, no one else
knows that art.
Thatís right.
Only I know it now.

- Can you teach me tap dancing?
- Where do you dance?
I donít dance, I work in a circus.
What turn do you do?
WellÖ itís no turnÖ
IÖ clean up the cages.
Fetch the trainers sodas.
What do you need the step for?
What step?
Thatís what tap dance is called.

I want to perform on the stage.
No one does tap dance now.
I can get famous overnight.
Iím afraid I wonít be able to help you.
Iíve never given private lessons.

And Iím very busy now.
A lot of work, you knowÖ

Itís really far too much.
Doing this, doing that.

You see, Alexei Ivanovich,
I have great abilities.

I can become such a great artist
that no one has seen yet.

I come from Vorkuta,
where one clever man told me:

ìArkady, youíre
something special.

You can become such a great artist
as no one has ever been.

You must go on the stage.
Donít waste your talent.î

So I left my home, came to Moscow,
doing all kind of odd jobs.
But I know I have to be an actor.

Time goes on,
but I got a talent.
I can see youíre a very good boy.

And possibly you do
possess the abilities.

Yet you should understand
that Iím a very busy man.

I got so much work, it just makes me
crazy.

I have to be everywhere at once,
very important business.

Doing this, doing that.
What can I do?
I will pay you.

Iíll pay you 5 rubles per lesson.
Itís good money.
Money wonít hurt you.
Of course, I do need money.

Iíve seen a sofa in a second-hand
shop that I want to buy.

A very good sofa, 60 rubles.
They donít make such things now.

With that kind of money you can
buy anything you want.

You like a thing, you have
money, you buy it.
I have everything, but I need a sofa.
Go and buy it! What the heck!
I donít knowÖ
I feel at a loss.

Youíre a funny fellow.
Moneyís coming into your hands.

It is one of those rare chances,
and youíre at a loss. Why?
All right, letís give it a try.

Come today at 5 to the pavilion.
You know where we work?

Look, since weíve
already agreed,

you might pay me
some advance?
How much?
WellÖ I donít know.
Five rubles, if itís not too much?
Here you are.
See you at 5.

Dear friends, it is my honor to
present to you our charming star,
Irina Melnikova!
Iím sure youíll agree with me

that Irinaíll bring new luster
to our program.

We must thank Irina
for having accepted

our invitation
to appear in our program.
Show me your walk.
Enough.

Now do this:
toe and heel, heel and toe.
Try it.

The beat!
The beat is the main thing.

Like a drummer, but instead
of sticks, use your feet.
Once again.

And your toe?
Pick up your toe, my boy.

I canít.
My leg was broken in two places.
Oh, I see.

- What?
- Nothing.
But I do have a good ear.

For a tap dancer, the main thing is
the feeling for rhythm. Letís test it.
Repeat it.

It was too fast.
Should do it like this.
Nothing wrong with your head?
No. Why?

Only a nut would want
to learn the step

with such a sense of rhythm, broken
bones and a walk like this.

Iím paying you for teaching me.
So, you teach.
How can I teach a man like you?
You think I canít make it at all?

I could make even
a baboon dance.

- You can? So do it.
- You can go to hellÖ
I wonít teach you.

- You wonít?
- I wonít.
Return the five rubles, then.

- What five rubles?
- The advance.
Here. The rest 4 Iíll pay later.

- Give me all five right now.
- I donít have them now.

Then teach me!
What were you saying?

Heel-toe, toe-heel.
Is it so?

Damn you!
Youíll go places.
Okay, no nonsense. Teach.

No hip waggling.
No hip waggling. Idiot.
Misha, my coat, please.

Next time Iíll throw your coat
in the trashcan.
All right, all right.

You people hang about here all day,
and I wait like a prisoner.

You couldíve worked on a thesis here,
youíd be a scholar now.

In America, a prisoner,
who spent his time writing,
won a Nobel Prize.

- My salary is enough for me.
- I didnít mean that.
What? Tired?

Why do you torment yourself in vain?
Itís quite useless.

- Itís none of your concern.
- Youíre right, it isnít.

You know why itís useless?
You donít have it.

Pacing, rhythm, feet,
all that is rubbish.

What you need in tap dance is
the spirit.

When you know that you can do
tap dance, and thatís it.

As though you canít
live without it.

You should feel as though you must
tap-dance now, orÖ perish!

Thatís how it should feel!
It is even terrifying.
You donít understand?

For example, you suddenly
feel an urge to do something.

Well, I donít know.
WhateverÖ you wishÖ to shout.

Here you sit, all alone.
And you feel like shouting.
Come on, shout! Now!
Itís because youíre empty like a drum.
I have a daughter.

She was only 3 years old,
but she had the spirit.
And she did the step like nobody.

I wanted to do a number with her
and show it on the stage.
She was such a clever kid.

When she saw I was angry,
she did the step.
She knew my weakness.
And did you do the number?

No.
My wife and I got divorced.
She took my daughter.
Sheís a bright young lady now!

Studies in a college, being
trained to be a diplomat.

And my ex happens to be a Peopleís
Artist of the USSR, by the way.

An opera singer.
Soboleva. Know her?
No, I donít.

So you mean
she walked out on you?

You stupid.
Irreconcilable differences.

With a Peopleís Artist
of the Soviet Union?

- Believe it or not.
- I believe it.

All right, I got to go.
See you Wednesday.
He believes it!

- Heís excellent!
- Yes.
Whoís he?
Thatís Lyosha Beglov.

He was a craze in his time,
around the ë50s.

A wonderful dancer.
Letís devise a program on him.

Weíll play this video
and invite Beglov.
It canít be done, he died.
When?

About 10 years ago, I had just
come back from Holland.
It was my first trip to Holland.

My wife said Iíd been
called to go to his funeral.

He was a fine fellow.
I knew him well.
He wouldíve been quite young then?
Let me see, Iím nowÖ Yes, about 40.
Forty?

Yes, forty. So sad, famous fellow,
casual relationships, heart attack.
And the man is no more.

We might play the video
and you tell his story.
Interesting idea.
Friends, how about making it

a regular monthly item,
ìForgotten Namesî?
And begin with Lyosha Beglov.
Great idea.
Yes, he certainly deserves it.
Good work.
Now they do it cheaply.

Just chipboard, some glue, and they
call it ìsofaî.
Nobody puts in real work.

Sergey, donít you sell it to
anybody, this sofa.

- Who would want it?
- Donít say that.

Just put it away,
hide it in some corner.

One day Iíll buy it and Iím going
to tip you, as I told you.

Listen, Beglov, youíd better not
potter around the shop.

Come on, Sergey,
Iím just looking around.
Iíll go home now. Bye.

Iím leavingÖ going straight home.
Thatís it. Goodbye.

Your good luck seems so tangible and
real,
But suddenly it proves but ephemeral.
It proves but ephemeral.

It rushes away in a cloud of glitter
and dust,
And we just stay behind, the outcasts.
Just stay behind, the outcasts.

Good fortune, good fortune, you make
us much richer,

But if fate would rather decide to
ditch it,

Weíll kiss you goodbye and sing
nevertheless,

Thereís time for a flop and time for
a success.
Weíre dancing out of sync.

Perhaps with luck it can be no other
way,

Now itís in your hands, now it slips
away.
Now it slips away.

The sudden good fortune, it goes to
our head,

And in feverish heat we lose all that
we had.
We lose all that we had.
What happened?
I donít like that hat.
Hello, Lyosha, hello.
Do you call them hats?

You really think you can make me
wear one of these?

You do all night I donít know what
and bring me this trash in the morning?

Iím Irina Melnikova, not some
Tyutkina.

Iím not going on the stage dressed
like a scarecrow because of you!

Get out!
Get lost, I say!
Shut up.

What?
Who are you talking to?
You.

- Me?
- Yes, you.
Who is he?

Heís our dance coach,
Irina Pavlovna.
Ah, a dance coach.

Then youíd better decide whom you
need more, the dance coach or me.
Now look here, Alexei Ivanovich.

Iím sorry, but I must
ask you to resign.
Make it on personal grounds.

You shouldnít have.
Irina Pavlovna always shouts,

but makes it up later
by showering gifts.

- Alexei Ivanovich.
- Goodbye.

- Goodbye.
- All the best.
Alexei Ivanovich.

Hello.
Here I am for my lesson.

What lesson?
My boss just kicked me out.
Kicked you out? What for?

You know Melnikova?
Our programís star?

She shouted at the costume girl.
I told her to keep quiet, and was fired.

- Who made you do that silly thing?
- No one.

No use crying over spilt milk.
Youíll find another job.

Thank God, itís not a capitalist
system weíre living in.
Of course Iíll find a job.

But all my life Iíve worked in variety.
What else can I do?

- Apologize to the big star.
- No.
All right, shall I fix it for you?
Howíll you fix it?
Where does she live?
I donít know.

- Who do you want?
- Irina Melnikova.
I shall ask her.
Name please?
Celentano.

Irina Pavlovna,
thereís a Celentano to see you.

- Who?
- Celentano.

- What Celentano?
- Adriano.
Adriano.
Irina, we love you!
Alexei Ivanovich!
Alexei Ivanovich, come on up!
Come in.
Come in.
Wipe your feet.

Give me your coat.
Everythingís all right.

Actually, sheís a nice dame.
She called Fomenko

and gave him a bit of her mind
about his arbitrary decision.

When she learnt you were a tap dancer,
she was delighted.

- She wants you to turn out something.
- Turn out what?

Dance. Sheís got company,
very decent people.
This is Alexei Ivanovich Beglov.

- Good evening.
- Good evening.

Hello. Celentano told us how
beautifully you do the step.
Yes, youíll see now.
Come on in.
Pianist ñ Adriano Celentano!
Your choice, Alexei Ivanovich?
Do you care for a drink?

I donít drink.
I had a heart attack.

- Whatís wrong?
- Nothing.

Why did you leave?
What happened?
Nothing happened.

- Something you didnít like?
- I liked everything.
No, something put you off.
Nothing put me off.
Only Iím not a performing monkey.
You mean Iím a monkey?
Youíre a monkey.
And who are you?!
Putting on airs.

- Why did he leave?
- Well, forget himÖ
Itís just outrageous!
Whereís the dancer, Celentano?
Heís gone.
Then you dance.
Whatís so funny?
Letís have it. Dance.
Stop that, Igor.

Stop what?
Whyís he here, then?

Iím here
because Iím your friend.

Oleg is the designer
who dresses you.
Mila is his girl.

And ChikaÖ no one knows him,
yet heís always around.

He is just taken for granted.
But who is he?

Why are you
so difficult today?

I just want to know who he is
and what heís doing here?
Or maybe heís a candidate for yourÖ
Stop it now!
Yet, who are you?
Heís Celentano.
Whatís your name, by the way?
Adriano.
Ready, everybody?
Ready, everybody?
Start.

Stop!
That was very nice.

Thatíll be all for today.
Thanks, everybody.

- What time tomorrow?
- Like today.
Letís begin.
You been drinking?
Beglov, you must teach me tap dancing.
I canít teach you when youíre drunk.
Teach me, I beg you.
Iím no monkey!
Get up, you drunkard!
You just wait!
How did I get here?
A stork brought you.

What a pig you are! Seeking solace
in drink. Shame on you!

No sermons please. My head is
bursting.
So you do have a head!

Listen, who needs to learn
the step? You or I?

I know the tricks of the trade,
thank God.

And what kind of
philosophy is that?

Is this the normal attitude to work
of todayís young folk?

I, for exampleÖ remember
myself at your age.
I worked day and night.

A job in the day and doing the step
at night like crazy. Hence the result.

Young men today
prefer it the easy way.

Work less
and get more.

Besides, he began to drink.
Thatís a real disaster.
Remember:

art and drink
are completely incompatible.

Whatís the matter with you?
Are you addressing a meeting?
I still donít understand.

Tell me, are you really like that
or just putting it on?

- Like what?
- Like that, indifferent.

Listen, lay off.
I feel sick and tired as it is.
And why are you so tired?

Have you been working on the Dnieper
Electric Station?
Or dug the Karakum Canal?
Or built the Moscow University?

Just look at this tired man!
He didnít lift a finger.
Oh, but heís tired.

Thatís why they make you run errands
for them, your employers,

and you keep running,
and will do it all your life.
Go to hellÖ
Just look at him.
He doesnít like it.
We move on to present our new program,
starting this week.

Itís called ìForgotten Namesî,
bringing to you
great artists of the past.
My God! Itís me.

Dear friends, youíve just seen a rare
video

showing
the wonderful art
of a great tap dancer,
Alexei Ivanovich Beglov.

The TV viewers belonging
to the older generation

will surely remember
this legendary artist,

who was the idol, I would say,
of the fifties.
Unfortunately,

Alexei Ivanovich
left this world
in the prime of his life.
And with that this great art

of tap dancing
came to a sudden endÖ

What? What díyou meanÖ left this
world?
What are you saying?!

And now our next
item, ìPopular Namesî.
Play the video, please.
Hey, wait!
We all are dreaming to see wonder,
But thereís no more wondrous thing

Than our earth that spreads heavens
under,
Where I live in an old house wingÖ
Hello?
Hello.

Good evening.
May I speak to Tatiana Sergeyevna?

Sheís in the theatre.
Whoís calling?
Her former husband, Beglov.

Good evening, Alexei Ivanovich.
Iím her husband. Any message for her?
No.

Just now the television showed
a program on me.

- Really?
- Yes. They announced that Iím dead.

Really?
On what channel?

- On first.
- So theyíll repeat it tomorrow.
Weíll definitely watch it.
No, donít.
You see, Iím alive.

I understand.
What shall we do?

Donít do anything. I just want you
to know that Iím safe and sound.
Okay, Iíll tell her that.

- Arkady, did you watch the TV?
- No.

They just announced
that Iím dead.

Are you a member of the Government
to announce your death?

I swear they announced Iím dead.
Can you imagine?
Itís not impossible.

- What díyou mean?
- Just that.

You worked on Dnieper Station, dug
the Karakum and built the university.

Thatís enough to kill a man.
Whatís so strange?

No jokes, please.
What shall I do now?

Set up a memorial.
A stele of pink tuff. How about it?
I swear. You just left,

and they ran this program, ìForgotten
Namesî.

They showed me and said that,
unfortunately, I was no longer alive.

Maybe youíve gone crazy
because of your megalomania?

What mania?
What shall I do?

I want to see all those who presented
the last ìMusical Panoramaî.

A scandalous incident.
It has never happened before.

Weíll take most strict action.
Iím sure itíll never happen again.
What about him?

- What about him?
- What díyou mean, what?

You pronounced the man dead,
and heís alive.

Comrade Beglov, please accept
our most sincere apologies.

In our next program weíll say
there was a misunderstanding,
that Comrade Beglov is alive and well.
Iím sure itíll make everybody happy.

Alexei Ivanovich,
youíll live a long life.

Thereís a belief that anyone buried
before his time is sure to live long.
Thank you.

- Which way now, Arkady?
- Homeward.

Letís go and celebrate
my rebirth.
Youíre like a chameleon, arenít you?

First you brand me a drunkard,
now you invite me for a drink.
Hello?

- Hello, Lena.
- Whoís this? Oh, hi, Dad.

- Howís life?
- Normal.
Remember we did tap dancing together?
Of course I remember.
Letís meet and do it again?

- Are you crazy, Dad?
- Why?
Iíve my exam tomorrow.

Well, sorry.
Howís your mom? Is she home?
Theyíre at the dacha.

Have you been watching
television lately?
No. Why?

Nothing special. Only you must
know Iím alive and well.
Thatís good, Dad.

- YesÖ well, bye.
- Bye.

Kolya! The Sphinx!
To the right! Move it.
Valera, what kind of capers are these?
How long must I go on?
As long as is necessary.

Once again from the beginning.
Take your places.

- Alexei Ivanovich?
- Yes.
What is it theyíre saying about you?

- What?
- Look, itís Beglov!

Yesterday they said on TV
that you were dead.

We pooled in the money
for a handsome wreath.

It was a mistake. They promised
to announce that Iím alive.
Now that sure is good news.
Youíll live long now!
I know, thatís what people say.
What shall we do with the money?
Letís buy Alexei Ivanovich a present.

- Okay, now back to work.
- Enough, girls, get to work.

- So, youíre quite a celebrity.
- Well, I was.
I liked your number very much.

I thought we could revive it and
include in our program.
What díyou say?

- Who will dance it?
- Who?

Weíll find somebody.
Who is a good tap dancer today?
No one.

- Is there really no one?
- No.
Too bad.

What a nice number itíd be.
Retro! Well, then.

All right, letís do it from
the beginning.

Valera, Olga, Ira! This is no
fish market. Calm down, will you?
Come on, guysÖ
Attention! Attention!

Letís work,
if you want to go on tour.

Weíre not going anywhere.
Weíre not the Bolshoi Theatre.
Youíre wrong.

A decisionís been taken today
to send our troupe to Rumania.

So, back to work.
Valera! Valera!

Begin from where
you left off, with jumps.
Come on, jump!

- Am I going, too?
- Of course.
How did it go?
Hello, Arkady.
Hi.
Can you spare a minute?

- Hi, Arkady!
- Hi!

- Itís an important matter.
- What is it?

Our choreographer wants to revive
my number ìGaucho, the tap dancerî.
Iíd like you to do it.
Didnít you want to be a tap dancer?

- Yes, but no longer.
- Why not?
WellÖ I gave up on the step.
Why did you decide to give it up?
You just surprise me.

You told me Iíll never
make a tap dancer.

I said you had a bad
manner of walking.

Sense of rhythm was lacking. But I
didnít say you couldnít make it.

- And you didnít mention the spirit?
- Yes, I did say that.

Well, I simply donít
have that spirit.
It will come.

- Oh, come on now!
- Are you going to learn?
Leave me alone!

- You must learn the step.
- I wonít.

- You will!
- Whatís that?!
You will!
Youíre like a small child.
Beglov!
Alexei Ivanovich!
In the broad strips of light and air,
The bee sought some kind of gold,
Visiting flower after flower, for
The nectar they might hold.
And a worm crawling in the grass,
Looked at it, and said ìAlas,
In my wildest dreams I cannot
Fly around like that.î
Yet, in agony, he cried out,
And to the bee he said:
ìO lift me from the grass, o bee,
So I can be with thee.î

- Lena?
- Hello, Dad.

- I woke you up, did I?
- No, come in.
Itís a niceÖ surprise.
Come on in. One second.
I had come to see you last night.
Yes, I was out.

You see, I was
tidying up a bit.

- Will you have breakfast with me?
- No, I must go.

What díyou mean ìmust goî?
You come so rarely. No.

- You must stay for breakfast.
- Some other time, Dad.
Iím getting married.
Getting married? To whom?

Heís a journalist.
Youíll meet him soon.
Why get married?

What díyou find so strange about it?
Girls usually do get married.
Oh yes, I just meantÖ
Is he a good man?

How can I tell?
I havenít lived with him yet.

- Do you love the man?
- I like him.

What do you mean?
Do you love him or not?

- I love him.
- Congratulations, then.
Whenís the wedding?

Thatís what I wanted
to talk to you about.

Donít worry, Iíll do everything
for my daughter.
Itís not that, Dad.

You see, thereís one thing,
I donít even know how to say it.
Go on.

WellÖ Donít come
to the marriage ceremony.
Why not?

Itíll be so awkward.
Dmitri Vasilyevich and you.
He brought me up, you see.

Theyíll drink to the parentsí health
and heíll be called my father.
PleaseÖ Dad.

Igor and I will come
to meet you the next day.

Weíll go somewhere,
spend the day together.
Dad, you donít mind, do you?
No, no, not at all.

In fact, I wonít be able to come
anyway.

Of course, I canít. Weíre off
to Rumania on a tour.
How could I forget about Rumania?

Then weíll meet
when you come back.
Yes, of course.

In the broad strips of light and air,
The bee sought some kind of gold,
Visiting flower after flower, for
The nectar they might hold.
And a worm crawling in the grass,
Looked at it, and said, ìAlas,
In my wildest dreams I cannot
Fly around like that.î
Yet, in agony, he cried out,
And to the bee he said:
ìO lift me from the grass, o bee,
So I can be with thee.î
And the wormís sighing ah and oh
In a pool of tears of his own.
Buzzing over him is the bee,
Ever full of mirth and glee.
When you, my friend, delight me so
With your gaze ingenuous and bright,
The earth and sky begin to glow
In a majestic, colorful light.
The hour of joy, the pain of separation

Iím willing to share with you,
my friend.

Let us shake hands and have no
hesitation

To set on the road for years without
end.
Weíre so close, no need to mention,

To remind each other, as if itís not
enough,
That our feeling and our friendship

Are more than passion, more than
simply love.
The hour of joy will be ours, rather,
You will come back, and only then
Weíll give a promise to each other
To be together and never part again.
Best of luck, Alexei Ivanovich!

MUSICAL PANORAMA

Iím especially happy today to
present to you our program.
I think youíll understand why.

In our last program ìForgotten
Namesî we featured

a wonderful tap dancer of
the ë50s, Alexei Beglov.
Heaps of letters have come

saying you all remember
and love Beglov.

Youíll be happy to know, friends,
that Alexei Ivanovich is alive
and in excellent health.

And now heís busy passing on his art
to up and coming artists of today.

In our next program

and talk with him,
as they say, live.
And now please watch a filmstrip

A number by Alexei Beglov.
I must say, Alexei Ivanovich,
you danced top class.
Yes, I was a top-class tap dancer.

You know, Iíve lived
a pretty satisfying life.

I loved dancing,
and I danced.

There were many people
whom I loved.

My fans loved me.
I had name, fame, money.

Yet I now remember
one night.

Only one night
in my life.

It happened many years ago,
in winter, in Gagry.
The stage was very small.

Season ending,
the audience was very thin.
I danced with my little girl.

She made me make her
my dancing partner.

Never in my life
did I dance so well.
Never in my life.
And you knowÖ

If only I could bring back
that wonderful eveningÖ
Iíd be willing to give everythingÖ
every last minute of my life.
